12.96.text:
What is the intersection
between technology, art and science?

20.90.text: because it drives us to explore,

23.65.text:
because we're surrounded
by things we can't see.

27.11.text:
And I love to use film
to take us on a journey

30.06.text: through portals of time and space,

45.94.text:
So here are some scenes
from my 3D IMAX film,

53.80.text:
There is movement which is too slow
for our eyes to detect,

58.25.text: and time lapse makes us discover

61.40.text: and broaden our perspective of life.

63.79.text: We can see how organisms emerge and grow,

68.04.text:
how a vine survives by creeping
from the forest floor

77.80.text:
time lapse allows us to see
our planet in motion.

82.88.text:
We can view not only
the vast sweep of nature,

85.72.text: but the restless movement of humanity.

89.35.text:
Each streaking dot
represents a passenger plane,

92.65.text:
and by turning air traffic data
into time-lapse imagery,

96.22.text:
we can see something
that's above us constantly

100.30.text:
the vast network of air travel
over the United States.

105.87.text:
We can do the same thing
with ships at sea.

108.83.text:
We can turn data into a time-lapse view
of a global economy in motion.

121.68.text:
And decades of data give us
the view of our entire planet

127.59.text:
sustained by currents circulating
throughout the oceans

130.86.text:
and by clouds swirling
through the atmosphere,

139.94.text: It may be the ultimate time-lapse image:

144.17.text: the anatomy of Earth brought to life.

153.29.text:
there are things that move
too fast for our eyes,

156.70.text:
but we have technology
that can look into that world as well.

164.93.text: we can do the opposite of time lapse.

168.33.text:
that are thousands of times
faster than our vision.

173.00.text:
And we can see how nature's
ingenious devices work,

176.99.text: and perhaps we can even imitate them.

186.72.text: but it's the greatest flier in nature.

196.48.text:
And by tracking markers
on an insect's wings,

199.58.text:
we can visualize the air flow
that they produce.

204.69.text: but high speed shows that a dragonfly

207.32.text:
can move all four wings
in different directions

211.68.text:
And what we learn can lead us
to new kinds of robotic flyers

225.69.text:
and we're unaware of things
that are too small for us to see.

228.75.text:
The electron microscope
fires electrons which creates images

233.37.text:
which can magnify things
by as much as a million times.

237.42.text: This is the egg of a butterfly.

241.46.text:
And there are unseen creatures
living all over your body,

244.54.text:
including mites
that spend their entire lives

249.29.text: crawling over your skin at night.

252.72.text: Can you guess what this is?

264.41.text: The eye of a fruit fly.

284.10.text:
We think we know
most of the animal kingdom,

286.47.text: but there may be millions of tiny species

294.99.text: A spider also has great secrets,

297.78.text:
because spiders' silk thread
is pound for pound stronger than steel

303.74.text:
This journey will take us
all the way down to the nano world.

307.99.text:
The silk is 100 times thinner
than human hair.

317.02.text: and near that bacteria, 10 times smaller,

329.74.text:
And nearing the limit
of our most powerful microscopes,

337.79.text: With the tip of a powerful microscope,

342.16.text: and begin to create amazing nano devices.

347.83.text:
Some could one day patrol our body
for all kinds of diseases

351.92.text:
and clean out clogged arteries
along the way.

356.10.text: Tiny chemical machines of the future

359.08.text: can one day, perhaps, repair DNA.

363.08.text:
We are on the threshold
of extraordinary advances,

366.15.text:
born of our drive
to unveil the mysteries of life.

372.55.text: So under an endless rain of cosmic dust,

375.48.text: the air is full of pollen,

379.26.text:
from other planets
and supernova explosions.

383.57.text:
People go about their lives
surrounded by the unseeable.

390.59.text:
Knowing that there's so much
around us we can't see

393.66.text:
forever changes
our understanding of the world,

396.82.text: and by looking at unseen worlds,

398.66.text:
we recognize that we exist
in the living universe,

401.43.text: and this new perspective creates wonder

404.31.text: and inspires us to become explorers

410.60.text: Who knows what awaits to be seen

413.04.text:
and what new wonders
will transform our lives.
